qas.question: What Roman Emperor became the ruler of all of Greece?
What saying by Horace became famous?

answers.text: "Greece, although captured, took its wild conqueror captive"

qas.question: What famous Roman figure visited Greece in 66 AD?
What famous Grecian author inspired later authors and their works?
What hero of Rome studied Greek philosophy and science?

context: The process was completed in 27 BC when the Roman Emperor <a0_0>Augustus<a0_0/> annexed the rest of Greece and constituted it as the senatorial province of Achaea. Despite their military superiority, the Romans admired and became heavily influenced by the achievements of Greek culture, hence Horace's famous statement: Graecia capta ferum victorem cepit (<a1_0>"Greece, although captured, took its wild conqueror captive"<a1_0/>). The epics of <a3_0>Homer<a3_0/> inspired the Aeneid of Virgil, and authors such as Seneca the younger wrote using Greek styles. Roman heroes such as <a4_0>Scipio Africanus<a4_0/>, tended to study philosophy and regarded Greek culture and science as an example to be followed. Similarly, most Roman emperors maintained an admiration for things Greek in nature. The Roman Emperor <a2_0>Nero<a2_0/> visited Greece in AD 66, and performed at the Ancient Olympic Games, despite the rules against non-Greek participation. Hadrian was also particularly fond of the Greeks; before he became emperor he served as an eponymous archon of Athens.
